bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to [John Holloway], August 25, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to his attorney and friend, John Holloway, August 25, 1720, concerning the lawsuit between his sister-in-law, Mary (Landon) Jones Swan, and her husband, noting that she "lyes at the Mercy of her Mortal Enemy" who wishes to leave her a meagre living, and is boasting that he will appeal the case to England if he should not win his appeal to the General Court in Virginia. Carter also thanks Holloway for his letter informing Carter that the mortgage between Carter and Edmund Jenings had been executed.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to [John Holloway], August 25, 1720
div1.p:
I have writ a Joint Lettr. to Yor.self & Mr. Atturney
relateing to my poor Distresd Sister Swans Case who now lyes
at the Mercy of her Mortal Enemy to turn her out of her being
when he pleases upon his allowing her a poor mean maintenance
God knows for a Gentlewoman and Yett this wont Sattisfye
him, he vants & boasts If he cant sett aside the Decree at the
General Court he'l Carry It for England but there Ill leave him
at presents

Yor. last Lettr. wch. tells me You had taken
care of the Execution of the Mortgage between Collo J[ennin] gs & I
came to my hands for the wch. I return You my Thanks & am in all respects——
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor. Sinceer & Afft. humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 44-45.
The county and colony have been added for clarity to RC's home address of "Corotman."
[1] To vaunt is to boast or brag. (Oxford English Dictionary)
